div1.p: Agramonte confidentially tells Kean of his and Noguchi's scientific disagreements. [Courtesy of The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia Library]

div1.head: Letter from Aristides Agramonte to Jefferson Randolph Kean, October 13, 1927
div1.opener:
TC-4336
II
DR. ARISTIDES AGRAMONTE
CALLE K, ENTRE 15 Y 17
VEDADO, HABANA
October 13th, 1927
Col. J. R. Kean, Ret.
Army Medical Museum,
Washington, D. C.
My dear Col. Kean:
div1.p:
It pleased me very much to receive your let-
ter of the 5th inst. I am sorry that I failed to send you a copy of
my little pamphlet at the time I wrote it; no one, I am sure, was more
entitled to receive it, and so I am enclosing one now, with due apolo-
gies.

There can be no objection on my part, to your republishing it in
“The Military Surgeon”, as you suggest: although the story is old, the
results of the work there narrated were of such incalculable value,
that a repetition of its history will only serve to enhance it.

The telegrams received at the time from Capt. Stark, as mention-
ed in my article, are signed “Chief Surgeon” and I did not know that
he was taking your place temporarily; you may, of course, state this
in a foot-note, if you come to publish it.

I am also sending you a paper that I wrote many years before Nogu-
chi found the Leptospira, “Yellow Fever a Strictly Human Disease”:
also a copy of another paper, read in the presence of Noguchi, in
Jamaica, on account of which we locked horns, of course. Upon the oc-
casion, Noguchi said he would provide me with cultures of his Lepto-
spira so that I could do human-mosquito experiments, which I thought
were absolutely necessary before he could claim specificity for L. ic-
teroides, but he failed to keep his word and subsequently has treated
me with the utmost disdain. Sellards has already followed my suggest-
ion and the application of mosquitoes, 10, 20 and 30 days after being
fed with leptospira blood, failed to produce human yellow fever, (or
any other pathologic condition). These experiments have not been pub-
lished yet, I therefore do not wish to refer to them in print; I only
know about them through Sellards' and Theiler's kindness in letting
me see their protocols when I was in Boston last August. I will thank
you to keep this confidential, also.

closer.salute:
With my best wishes, I remain,
Very cordially,
